title: Strait of Hormuz De Facto Closure
description: Oil tankers avoiding Hormuz after US-Israel strikes on Iran. Insurance withdrawal creating de facto blockade. 20 million bbl/day flow at risk, 84% of which serves Asian markets. ASEAN crude and LNG supply chains severely disrupted.

title: Thailand Fuel Price Emergency
description: Thailand Energy Ministry warns of sharp diesel pump hike by March 4. Reserves at 61 days. Trade balance most oil-sensitive in ASEAN (-0.9%/$10bbl). Monitoring tanker flows through Hormuz and Red Sea.

title: Indonesia Fiscal Subsidy Crisis
description: Indonesia's 2026 budget assumes $70/bbl oil. With Brent expected $85-90+, fuel subsidy expenditure faces blowout. Government urged to adopt adaptive fiscal policies. Risk of forced fuel price deregulation triggering social unrest.

title: Singapore Refining Hub Under Pressure
description: Singapore, ASEAN's largest oil refining and trading hub, faces margin compression as crude feedstock costs surge. Trade balance sensitivity at -0.7%/$10bbl. Electricity and transport costs expected to rise. Australian LNG stocks surging as alternative supply sought.

title: Strait of Hormuz De Facto Closure
description: Vessel traffic dropped 70% after US-Israeli strikes on Iran. IRGC broadcasting 'no ship allowed to pass' on VHF. 200+ tankers anchored outside strait. Three tankers damaged by collateral fire. War risk insurance surging 50%, major carriers suspending all transits.

title: Singapore Transhipment Bottleneck Risk
description: Singapore, Tanjung Pelepas, and Port Klang face congestion risk as Gulf-bound cargo is rerouted. Vessels discharging at intermediate ports (Salalah, Colombo) for feeder redistribution. Container surcharges of $1,500-$4,000/TEU adding cost pressure across ASEAN supply chains.

title: Cape of Good Hope Rerouting Surge
description: Major carriers (Maersk, CMA CGM, Hapag-Lloyd) rerouting via Cape of Good Hope after Suez Canal transit suspended. Adds 10-14 days and $500K-$1.2M per voyage. Combined with Red Sea Houthi threat, creates dual chokepoint crisis with no short route alternative for Asia-bound cargo.

title: ASEAN LNG Supply Disruption
description: 83% of Hormuz LNG volumes are Asia-bound. Nine LNG carriers simultaneously diverted from Hormuz on Feb 28. Thailand warned of 25% gas price hike by March 4. US LNG export infrastructure at capacity, limiting alternative supply. Southeast Asia faces acute energy security risk.

title: Strait of Hormuz Chokepoint Disruption
description: Trading houses suspend oil shipments through the Strait of Hormuz following Iranian naval threats. 84% of Hormuz crude flows go to Asia. If sustained, ASEAN faces energy supply crisis as the region imports majority of its oil via this corridor. Brent crude has surged 8-12% to $79-82/bbl.

title: Singapore Financial Hub Sanctions Compliance Pressure
description: Singapore-based banks and trading firms face heightened secondary sanctions risk following reimposition of UN sanctions on Iran (Sep 2025) and new US designations (Feb 2026). 18 Iranian banks are under secondary sanctions. Financial institutions must urgently review counterparty exposure to Iran-linked entities and shipping networks.

title: Thailand Inflation Surge Risk from Oil Price Shock
description: Thailand is the most trade-balance-sensitive ASEAN economy to oil price spikes (-0.9% impact). With 80% oil/gas energy mix and declining domestic reserves, sustained Brent above $90/bbl could reverse Thailand's recent deflation and trigger 1-2% CPI increase, pressuring THB and consumer spending.

title: Malaysia Windfall as Net Energy Exporter
description: Malaysia is ASEAN's only net oil and gas exporter, with its O&G sector projected at $9.66B in 2026. Higher oil prices from the Iran conflict provide positive terms-of-trade impact and fiscal revenue boost. MYR expected to outperform regional peers. Petronas deep-water investments position Malaysia to capture additional market share.

title: Malaysia Tables Parliamentary Motion Condemning Iran Strikes
description: PM Anwar Ibrahim tables Dewan Rakyat motion on March 2 condemning US-Israel assault on Iran, the strongest legislative response from any ASEAN nation. Malaysia stands in solidarity with Muslims and calls for immediate ceasefire, marking a significant departure from ASEAN's traditionally muted responses to Middle East conflicts.

title: Indonesia Offers Tehran Mediation as Neutral Broker
description: President Prabowo Subianto declares willingness to travel to Tehran to mediate US-Iran conflict. Iran's Jakarta embassy welcomes the offer. Indonesia positions itself as a neutral broker, avoiding direct condemnation of either side, but faces domestic criticism over feasibility. This marks Indonesia's most ambitious Middle East diplomatic initiative in decades.

title: ASEAN Diplomatic Unity Fractures Over Iran Response
description: Despite collective rhetoric of restraint, ASEAN members are divided: Malaysia and Vietnam lean pro-Iran, Singapore and Philippines maintain careful neutrality as US allies, and Thailand focuses on evacuation logistics. No formal joint ASEAN statement issued under Philippines' 2026 chairmanship. The crisis tests ASEAN centrality and consensus-building mechanisms.

title: Singapore Balances US Alliance with Middle East Trade Ties
description: Singapore MFA expresses 'regret' over failed negotiations without condemning either side, cancels flights to the region, and advises citizens to defer travel. As a US security partner with significant Middle East trade exposure, Singapore's carefully calibrated neutrality reflects the tension between alliance commitments and economic pragmatism that defines its Iran-crisis diplomacy.

title: US Carrier Gap in South China Sea
description: USS Abraham Lincoln CSG redirected from SCS to Middle East, leaving only USS George Washington. China increased patrol tempo and signal jamming operations. 500+ US-Philippines exercises planned for 2026 but carrier-level deterrence degraded.

title: Strait of Malacca Elevated Security Risk
description: Hormuz closure rerouting oil traffic increases Malacca throughput and piracy exposure. Historical Hezbollah target list includes vessels in Singapore Strait and Malacca. INDOMALPHI trilateral patrols under increased operational pressure.

title: Philippines Defense Modernization & ASEAN Summit Security
description: Record 500+ US-PHL joint exercises in 2026. New OPV deliveries from South Korea. Philippine Navy conducting ASEAN Summit security patrols. But Chinese signal jamming and SCS confrontations escalating amid US distraction.

title: Iran Cyber Retaliation Threat to ASEAN Financial Hubs
description: FBI on high alert for Iran retaliation including cyberattacks. Singapore and ASEAN financial systems potential targets. Iran-linked actors increasingly using RaaS for plausible deniability. Southeast Asia's existing cybercriminal ecosystem could be leveraged.

title: Strait of Hormuz De Facto Closure Disrupts ASEAN Feedstock Supply
description: US-Israel strikes on Iran triggered insurance withdrawal and 70% vessel traffic drop through Hormuz. 20% of global oil, 33% of fertilizers, and critical petrochemical feedstocks (methanol, ethylene, LPG) transiting the strait are disrupted, directly impacting ASEAN petrochemical, plastics, and agricultural sectors.

title: ASEAN Fertilizer Crisis Threatens Rice Belt Food Security
description: Iran's urea production collapse (single plant operational) and Hormuz disruption cut ASEAN access to 33% of global fertilizer trade. Thailand, Vietnam, Philippines face 10-15% fertilizer cost increases threatening rice production costs and food affordability for 600M+ people in food-import-dependent Southeast Asian nations.

title: Malaysia-Singapore Petrochemical Hub Faces Feedstock Shortage
description: Malaysia and Singapore petrochemical complexes face 15-25% feedstock cost increases as Iranian methanol and Gulf naphtha supplies are disrupted. Regional refining margins under pressure from simultaneous Chinese product dumping and feedstock shortages. Long-term shift to alternative suppliers (Trinidad, Chile, expanded Chinese methanol) underway.

title: Vietnam Plastics Industry Squeezed by Dual Disruption
description: Vietnam's plastics and packaging sector faces simultaneous pressure from Chinese manufacturers flooding ASEAN markets with cheap product AND Gulf feedstock cost inflation from Hormuz closure. Long Son complex (1.65M t/y ethylene) provides partial domestic buffer but naphtha price volatility threatens margins across automotive, electronics, and packaging supply chains.
